title: Baby strangled by umbilical cord because she grew too big in mum’s womb
text:
Georgina and partner Dave Squire while 35 weeks pregnant with their baby Rosie (Picture: Georgina Hardy/Metro.co.uk)

A mother whose baby was stillborn at 42 weeks is campaigning for greater awareness of the risks involved with being overdue.

Georgina Hardy, 26, and her partner Dave Squire, 26, were beyond excited to meet their baby daughter after the ‘perfect’ pregnancy.

Having reached their due date the couple, from Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, believed they were out of the danger zone and it was just a matter of time before their baby arrived.

But at 39 weeks, their baby stopped moving. Georgina went into hospital for tests and some movement was detected, so she was told to go home.

At 42 weeks, now overdue, the baby stopped moving again. Scans could not detect a heartbeat.

In February, Georgina and Dave’s daughter Rosie Melanie Joyce Squire was stillborn.

She was by this point three weeks overdue and died because her umbilical cord became wrapped around her neck.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Georgina told Metro.co.uk: ‘She was allowed to grow too big and was slowly strangled.’

Georgina and Dave had no idea any complications could arise from being overdue (Picture: Georgina Hardy/Metro.co.uk)

Georgina has launched a campaign to challenge the protocol of allowing women to go beyond full term, which is around the 40 week mark.

Most pregnant women are fine to go over their due date by up to two weeks which is the normal time an induction is booked.

But studies have found that when pregnancies last for 40 weeks or longer, there is an increase in the risk of stillbirth and neonatal death.

The risks are small but they are there and Georgina argues all pregnant women should be made aware of them.

She said: ‘You get to the 38 week mark and think, “I’ve made it”, it’s just a waiting game now, waiting for the baby to be here.

‘We never for one second thought we wouldn’t have a baby at the end of it.

‘Everyone is very aware of the risk of miscarriage at the beginning of a pregnancy, we all know that those first 12 weeks are high risk, yet no-one ever speaks about there being risks at the end of the pregnancy too.’

The couple had photos taken with Rosie thanks to a charity called Remember My Baby (Picture: Georgina Hardy/Metro.co.uk)

Georgina claims that in a post-mortem meeting with her doctors following Rosie’s birth, medics admitted letting her go to 42 weeks was a ‘mistake’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

She said: ‘They said I should have been induced at 39 weeks but they didn’t follow procedure. They said it was essentially a mistake.

‘It would have been an emergency C-section at 39 weeks, but at the end of the day, we would now have a healthy eight month old baby.

‘I went home and started searching online – was this something I did wrong? What should I have done differently?

‘Then I discovered all these risks associated with going overdue. I was horrified. Not once was I told anything about the risk of stillbirth after 40 weeks.

‘I understand they don’t want to scare mums – but we are told about the 12 week mark, why aren’t we warned of the post-40 week mark too?’

Georgina said that not being made aware of the risks made her feel ‘let down’ by the NHS.

She said: ‘What really really upset me is that throughout the whole of my pregnancy I was repeatedly told that because of my BMI I was “high risk”.

‘I did everything right, I did everything I was supposed to do and I brought my baby to full term.

‘The one time I needed them to act on the fact I was “high risk” they didn’t do it.’

The couple said midwives at Colchester Hospital’s bereavement suite were amazing and allowed them to stay with Rosie for three days after her birth (Picture: Georgina Hardy/Metro.co.uk)

Georgina and Dave were given a room at Colchester Hospital’s bereavement suite, which they said was incredible during the most heartbreaking time.

Advertisement

Midwives were ‘amazing’, Georgina said, and the hospital allowed the couple to spend three days with their baby, Rosie, after she was born.

She said: ‘It was like we had a real baby for a little while. They did all they could for us.

‘It’s just a shame that service has to exist.’

She said she did not hold it against those who treated her as ‘they were following protocol’ but added: ‘I think that protocol should change.’

Georgina wanted to speak out about her experience after finding out the joyful news she is pregnant once again.

She said: ‘I think that’s what has spurred me into sharing this information. This time round it feels totally different.

Georgina and Dave are expecting again and are now 15 weeks pregnant with Rosie’s sibling (Picture: Georgina Hardy/Metro.co.uk)

‘It feels like we are being treated the way we should have been treated last time. I’ve been told I won’t ever be allowed to go past 39 weeks again.

‘And I am questioning everything I am told. It’s a shame because I don’t fully trust and I know that I won’t truly be worry free until we have a baby in our arms.

‘We simply can’t enjoy this pregnancy.’

The couple are still waiting for a final meeting with their doctors next week where they are hoping they will find out what exactly went wrong.

Advertisement

Catherine Morgan is Chief Nurse at East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust, which runs Colchester Hospital.

She said: ‘Our top priority is to provide safe, high quality, compassionate health services to the patients we care for every day at the Trust.

‘We have carried out a full investigation into what happened after the very sad stillbirth of Miss Hardy’s baby and we express our sincerest condolences to her and her family. We will be meeting with her next week to talk through the findings of that review.

‘Patient safety and the delivery of high quality care is very important to us and we strive to continually improve, so we take any lessons learned from our investigations forward to better our services.’

To support Georgina’s campaign, visit her petition website here.
